db:abstract.db:para: This class was introduced in Qt 2.0.

db:note.db:para: All functions in this class are reentrant with the following exceptions:

db:para.db:para: Test is part of testgroupTest C++ Types

db:section.db:title: enum Test::ScopedEnum
db:section.db:para: This enum has a brief to trigger a bug in CMD_BRIEF.
A scoped enum.

db:section.db:title: Test::SomeType
db:section.db:para: A typedef.

db:section.db:title: [protected] void Test::overload()
db:section.db:para: Overloads that share a documentation comment, optionally taking a parameter b.

db:section.db:title: [noexcept default] Test::Test()
db:section.db:para: Default constructor.

db:section.db:title: void (*)(bool) Test::funcPtr(bool b, const char *s)
db:section.db:para: Returns a pointer to a function that takes a boolean. Uses b and s.

db:section.db:title: void Test::inlineFunction()
db:section.db:para: An inline function, documented using the \fn QDoc command.

db:section.db:title: void Test::methodWithEmDashInItsDocs()
db:section.db:para: This method has em dashes in its documentation—as you'll find represented by --- in the sources—here and there. The important bit to note is that when passed e.g. to the \c command, the three hyphens are processed as input to the command and not replaced by an em dash.
People can still add a bunch of dashes, though, without QDoc replacing them all with a series of em dashes.
—You can also start a new paragraph with an em dash, if you want to.

db:section.db:title: void Test::methodWithEnDashInItsDocs()
db:section.db:para: This method has en dashes in its documentation – as you'll find represented by -- in the sources – here and there. The important bit to note is that when passed e.g. to the \c command, the two hyphens are processed as input to the command and not replaced by an en dash. This also applies to code blocks, where otherwise, the decrement operator would get completely borked:
db:section.db:programlisting: for (int i = 42; i > 0; --i) // Do something cool during countdown.
db:section.db:para: ...as it would be silly if this would output –i instead of --i.
It still allows people to add a bunch of dashes, though, without replacing them all with a series of en dashes. Of course, they might want to use the \hr command instead, like this:
– You can also start a new paragraph with an en dash, if you want to.

db:section.db:title: int Test::someFunction(int, int v = 0)
db:section.db:para: Function that takes a parameter v. Also returns the value of v.

db:section.db:title: void Test::someFunctionDefaultArg(int i, bool b = false)
db:section.db:para: Function that takes a parameter i and b.

db:section.db:title: [virtual] void Test::virtualFun()
db:section.db:para: Function that must be reimplemented.

db:section.db:title: [noexcept default] TestQDoc::Test &Test::operator=(TestQDoc::Test &&other)
db:section.db:para: Move-assigns other.

db:section.db:title: bool operator==(const TestQDoc::Test &lhs, const TestQDoc::Test &rhs)
db:section.db:para: Returns true if lhs and rhs are equal.

db:section.db:title: [since Test 1.1] QDOCTEST_MACRO2(int &x)
db:section.db:para: A macro with argument x.
This macro was introduced in Test 1.1.

db:section.db:title: Obsolete Members for Test
db:section.db:para: The following members of class Test are deprecated. We strongly advise against using them in new code.

db:section.db:title: TestQDoc::Test &Test::operator++()
db:section.db:para: This function is deprecated. We strongly advise against using it in new code.

db:section.db:title: void Test::anotherObsoleteMember()
db:section.db:para: This function is deprecated. We strongly advise against using it in new code.
Use obsoleteMember() instead.

db:section.db:title: void Test::deprecatedMember()
db:section.db:para: This function is deprecated since 6.0. We strongly advise against using it in new code.
Use someFunction() instead.

db:section.db:title: void Test::obsoleteMember()
db:section.db:para: This function is deprecated. We strongly advise against using it in new code.
Use someFunction() instead.
